qas.question: What was stolen from Target Corporation computers in 2013?
How many credit card numbers were stole from Home Depot in 2014?
What machines were involved in the physical security breaches that played a large role in the incident?

answers.text: director of threat intelligence operations at security technology company McAfee

plausible_answers.text: Warnings were delivered at both corporations, but ignored

qas.question: What was done when credit cards were stolen?

plausible_answers.text: existing antivirus software had administrators responded to the warnings

qas.question: Who could have easily stopped the hacking?
Unsophisticated malware was used on what?
Who was the leader of Rescator?

plausible_answers.text: The malware utilized is absolutely unsophisticated and uninteresting

qas.question: Why weren't the companies warned about the threat?

context: In <b14_0>2013<b14_0/> and 2014, <a0_0>a Russian/Ukrainian hacking ring<a0_0/> known as "Rescator" broke into Target Corporation computers in 2013, stealing roughly <a1_0>40 million credit cards<a1_0/>, and then Home Depot computers in <b12_0>2014<b12_0/>, stealing <a2_0>between 53 and 56 million<a2_0/> <b11_0>credit card numbers<b11_0/>. <b5_0>Warnings were delivered at both corporations, but ignored<b5_0/>; physical security breaches using <a3_0><b6_0><b8_0>self checkout machines<b8_0/><b6_0/><a3_0/> are believed to have played a large role. "<b13_0>The malware utilized is absolutely unsophisticated and uninteresting<b13_0/>," says <b10_0>Jim Walter<b10_0/>, <a4_0>director of threat intelligence operations at security technology company McAfee<a4_0/> – meaning that the heists <b9_0>could have easily been stopped<b9_0/> by <b7_0>existing antivirus software had administrators responded to the warnings<b7_0/>. The size of the thefts has resulted in major attention from state and Federal United States authorities and the investigation is ongoing.
